content.text: The diameter \(d\) of a cylinder is measured as \(0.0125 \text{m} \pm 1.6\%\)
Calculate the absolute uncertainty in this measurement
absolute uncertainty =   .........  m
Calculate the pressure \(p\)
Determine the absolute uncertainty in the value of \(p\)
absolute uncertainty =   .........  Nm\(^{-2}\)
The cylinder in **(a)** stands on a horizontal surface. The pressure \(p\) exerted on the surface by the cylinder is given by
The measured weight \(W\) of the cylinder is \(0.38 \text{N} \pm 2.8\%\)
State Newton's second law of motion
Calculate the distance travelled by the car from time \(t = 0\) to \(t = 10 \text{s}\)
distance =   .........  m
At time \(t = 10 \text{s}\), the resistive force acting on the car due to air resistance and friction is \(510 \text{N}\). The tension in the tow-bar is \(440 \text{N}\)
For the car at time \(t = 10 \text{s}\):
1. use Fig. 2.2 to calculate the acceleration
acceleration =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-2}\)
2. use your answer to calculate the resultant force acting on the car
resultant force =   .........  N
3. show that a horizontal force of \(1300 \text{N}\) is exerted on the car by its engine
4. determine the useful output power of the engine
output power =   .........  W
A car of mass \(850\mathrm{kg}\) tows a trailer in a straight line along a horizontal road, as shown in Fig. 2.1
The car and the trailer are connected by a horizontal tow-bar
The variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the car for a part of its journey is shown in Fig. 2.2
A short time later, the car in **(b)** is travelling at a constant speed and the tension in the tow-bar is 480 N
The tow-bar is a solid metal rod that obeys Hooke's law. Some data for the tow-bar are listed below
Determine the extension of the tow-bar
extension =   .........  m

The driver of the car in **(b)** sees a pedestrian standing directly ahead in the distance. The driver operates the horn of the car from time \(t = 15s\) to \(t = 17s\). The frequency of the sound heard by the pedestrian is \(480\mathrm{Hz}\). The speed of the sound in the air is \(340\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\)
Use Fig. 2.2 to calculate the frequency of the sound emitted by the horn
frequency =   .........  Hz
State what is meant by the centre of gravity of a body
Calculate the vertical component of the tension in the wire
vertical component of tension =   .........  N
Explain why the force on the sign at B does not have a moment about point A
By taking moments about point A, show that the weight \(W\) of the sign is \(150 \text{N}\)
Calculate the total vertical force exerted by the wall on the sign at points A and B
total vertical force =   .........  N
A uniform square sign with sides of length \(0.68 \text{m}\) is fixed at its corner points A and B to a wall. The sign is also supported by a wire CD, as shown in Fig. 3.1

The sign has weight \(W\) and centre of gravity at point E. The sign is held in a vertical plane with side BC horizontal. The wire is at an angle of \(35^{\circ}\) to side BC. The tension in the wire is \(54 \text{N}\)
The force exerted on the sign at B is only in the vertical direction

The sign in **(b)** is held together by nuts and bolts. One of the nuts falls vertically from rest through a distance of \(4.8 \text{m}\) to the pavement below. The nut lands on the pavement with a speed of \(9.2 \text{m s}^{-1}\)
Determine, for the nut falling from the sign to the pavement, the ratio
change in gravitational potential energy
final kinetic energy
displacement
amplitude
For a progressive water wave, state what is meant by:

Two coherent waves X and Y meet at a point and superpose. The phase difference between the waves at the point is \(180^{\circ}\). Wave X has an amplitude of \(1.2 \text{cm}\) and intensity \(I\). Wave Y has an amplitude of \(3.6 \text{cm}\)
Calculate, in terms of \(I\), the resultant intensity at the meeting point
intensity =
Monochromatic light is incident on a diffraction grating. Describe the diffraction of the light waves as they pass through the grating

A parallel beam of light consists of two wavelengths \(540\mathrm{nm}\) and \(630\mathrm{nm}\). The light is incident normally on a diffraction grating. Third-order diffraction maxima are produced for each of the two wavelengths. No higher orders are produced for either wavelength
Determine the smallest possible line spacing \(d\) of the diffraction grating
The beam of light in **(c)**(ii) is replaced by a beam of blue light incident on the same diffraction grating
State and explain whether a third-order diffraction maximum is produced for this blue light
State Kirchhoff's second law
Calculate:
1. the combined resistance of the two resistors connected in parallel
combined resistance =   .........  \(\Omega\)
2. the current in the battery
current =   .........  A
Show that the internal resistance \(r\) is \(2.5 \Omega\)
Determine the ratio
power dissipated by internal resistance \(r\)
total power produced by battery
A battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(5.6\mathrm{V}\) and internal resistance \(r\) is connected to two external resistors, as shown in Fig. 5.1
The reading on the voltmeter is 4.8 V
The battery in **(b)** is now connected to a battery of e.m.f. 7.2 V and internal resistance 3.5 \(\Omega\). The new circuit is shown in Fig. 5.2
Determine the current in the circuit
current =   .........  A
State what is meant by a _field line_ (line of force) in an electric field
An electric field has two different regions X and Y. The field strength in X is less than that in Y. Describe a difference between the pattern of field lines (lines of force) in X and in Y
Particle P and an \(\alpha\) -particle are in the same uniform electric field. Calculate the ratio
magnitude of acceleration of particle P
magnitude of acceleration of \(\alpha\) -particle
Particle P is a hadron composed of only two quarks. One of them is a down (d) quark
By considering charge, determine a possible type (flavour) of the other quark
Explain your working
A particle P has a mass of \(0.15 \text{u}\) and a charge of \(-1 \text{e}\), where \(e\) is the elementary charge
